title: Blog setup
text:
In this blog post I‚Äôll explain how I created this blog, using Quarto, GitHub (and GitHub Pages). I‚Äôm working on a Macbook, and using VS Code for code editing. If you are on a Linux or Windows machine, be aware that things might be a bit different from what I describe here.
I am assuming you already have a GitHub account, that you have VS Code installed and set up in a way that you can run Python and Jupyter Notebooks.

title: Blog setup
text:
Step 1: install Quarto
First of all you need to install Quarto, head over to here and download and install the software. You should do this on the machine that you want to use for writing your blog, in my case my Macbook laptop.
Once installed you will have access to the quarto Command Line Interface (CLI). To make sure everything works as expected, open a terminal and execute:
quarto --help
This should give some outputs describing the different commands and options that are part of the Quarto CLI and shows that Quarto is installed successfully.

title: Blog setup
text:
Step 2: create a GitHub repo
To host our blog, we will use GitHub Pages, which is a service to host a website from a GitHub repository. Based on the name you pick for your repository you will create a so-called ‚Äúproject website‚Äù or your unique ‚Äúuser website‚Äù. For any repo named my-awesome-repo, the website will be hosted on https://<github-username>.github.io/my-awesome-repo, this is what‚Äôs called a project website and you can create as many as you like.
You can create your ‚Äúuser website‚Äù by creating a repo called <github-username>.github.io, which will be hosted at https://<github-username>.github.io.
Since I want my blog to be hosted as ‚Äúuser website‚Äù, I thus create a new repo with the name: lucasvw.github.io.
I find it helpful to add a .gitignore file with a Python template, to which we can later add some more entries to facilitate storing the right files on GitHub. Also make sure that the repo is Public (and not set to Private). Additionally, I added a README file and choose the Apache2 License.
Next, I clone this repo to my machine by running the following command in the folder where I have all my code project.
git clone git@github.com:lucasvw/lucasvw.github.io.git

title: Blog setup
section: Step 3: create a Quarto project in the repo
text:
Step 3: create a Quarto project in the repo
Next, head over to VS Code, and open the cloned repo. Open the terminal inside of VS Code and run:
quarto create-project --type website:blog
This will add a number of files to our repo, which represent the basic structure of our blog. Most importantly:

posts: here we will create our blog entries (one subfolder per blog entry)
_quarto.yml: configuration file for our blog such as the theme, name, GitHub and Twitter links
about.qmd: source code for the ‚Äúabout‚Äù page.
index.qmd: source code for the landing page.







Note



.qmd files are like markdown files, but with lots of additional functionality from Quarto. Go here for more information on Markdown syntax and here for Quarto Markdown


To see what we currently have, let‚Äôs render our blog locally. We can do this by running
quarto preview
Alternatively, we can install the Quarto extension in VS Code, which will show a render button in the top right corner on any opened qmd file.
To publish to GitHub pages, we can run:
quarto publish gh-pages
When we run this, we get a message that we have to change the branch from which GitHub Pages builds the site. To do this, I go to https://github.com/lucasvw/lucasvw.github.io/settings/pages and select gh-pages instead of the main branch.
And voila, in a few moments our blog will be running live at https://lucasvw.github.io/

title: Blog setup
section: Step 4: finalize set-up and create first blog entry
text:
Step 4: finalize set-up and create first blog entry
When we run the quarto publish gh-pages command, Quarto processes our files and turns them into web readable files (HTML, JS, CSS etc). Next, it will push these files to the gh-pages branch. This is great, but it means that this doesn‚Äôt store our source files in GitHub.
To do so, let‚Äôs first open our .gitignore file and make sure that it contains the following entries:
# Quarto
/.quarto/
_site/

# Mac files
.DS_Store
Next, we can commit all the remaining files to Git and push them to our remote repo.
Finally, we can start tweaking our about.qmd files and create a new blog entry
